Award.AwardTitle: OCE-PRF: Metabolic Contributions to Climate Proxies and Untested Assumptions in the Hydrologic and Ecological Applications of Photoautotrophic Lipids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how the Earth's hydrologic and carbon cycles will respond to climatic changes, whether as a result of warming, ocean acidification, or other trends, is an important charge of the oceanographic and Earth-sciences communities. Human adaptation to changes in these cycles rests on accurate prediction of those changes; accurate prediction, in turn, requires an understanding of the mechanisms involved. One of the best ways to discern these mechanisms is detailed investigation of past behavior via sedimentary records. In this project, the fellow will investigate the hydrogen isotopic composition of algal cell water in order to test important assumptions regarding environmental proxies currently being developed for such studies of past climate.

The participation-broadening goals include producing and teaching material focused on the marine impacts of urban watersheds. This work will occur in collaboration with the Seattle chapter of MESA, a national organization dedicated to improving STEM education for economically disadvantaged youth, under-represented minorities, and women. The sponsoring scientist is Julian Sachs at the University of Washington College of the Environment.

Unicellular marine or lacustrine photoautotrophs (both algae and photosynthetic bacteria) have generally been assumed to have internal water pools that are isotopically identical to that of their growth environment. This has spurred numerous attempts to develop hydrologic proxies from thehydrogen isotopic composition of sedimentary lipids produced by these organisms, as these compounds incorporate hydrogen from the intracellular water pool. It has also become clear that, in certain settings, the large and variable vital effects relating water and lipid isotopic compositions (quantified as the net fractionation factor alpha) potentially record a wealth of ecological information important for studies of the carbon cycle. The community faces a challenge in further development of these isotopic proxies, however, as recent work has suggested that growth or metabolic rate may exert significant controls on intracellular hydrogen isotopic composition of water. To address this, the fellow will run a series of experiments to determine the isotopic response of intracellular water in photoautotrophs to growth. A series of chemostat culture experiments will be coupled with the novel Kreuzer isotope enrichment technique employed in previous metabolic water determinations. These experiments are designed to isolate the effects of cell division, light intensity, salinity, and growth phase on the hydrogen isotopic composition of the water available for lipid synthesis, and to determine the degree to which any changes are propagated into lipids. The proposed work may resolve an important open question regarding the fidelity of a whole class of promising environmental proxies. The quantification of isotopic differences between environmental and intracellular water in photoautotrophs may open new avenues of research for biologists across many fields, however, as these differences may trace cellular synthesis, respiration, and water exchange processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fats produced by photosynthesizing ocean plankton are increasingly used to reconstruct past climates by measuring the relative amount of different of 'heavy' and 'light' hydrogen isotopes they incorporate. All else being equal, changes in this ratio are thought to reflect changes the salinity the plankton grew at, or potentially other important measures such as growth rate, temperature, or the availability of light. However, the ultimate source of hydrogen to these lipids is the water inside the plankton cell, and it is unknown whether or not the isotopic ratio of this water can change, or if it simply reflects the composition of the surrounding ocean.

During the project, a novel isotopic labeling technique was used to measure the hydrogen isotope composition of the water inside a common marine diatom (single-cell photosynthesizing algae with silica shells). It was found that significant shifts in the composition of the cell water could occur depending on what time of day the samples were collected. When grown on a 12-hour-on, 12-hour-off light cycle, the water in cells collected near noon was highly enriched in 'heavy' hydrogen relative to cells collected near midnight. This is consistent with the knowledge that photosynthesis (which should occur most rapidly in the middle of the day) preferentially removes 'light' hydrogen, leaving the remaining water 'heavier'. Until now, it was not known whether or not this process could actually alter the measurable water inside the cell, or if this water was so rapidly replaced by water from the surrounding environment that no change occurred.

This knowledge serves as an important warning for those wishing to use algal fats as a tool to reconstruct salinity (or other parameters) across areas or times where different average photosynthetic rates would be expected. When additional data about cell water changes in response to different salinities is in hand (collected as part of the project, analysis pending), we will know whether the changes that drive the "salinity effect" used to reconstruct past climate are large or small relative to the changes in cell water we may expect due to changes in photosynthesis.

More directly, knowing that changes in cell water occur on time scales less than a day is of crucial importance for those wishing to probe biochemical mechanisms with heavy isotope tracers. Researchers have begun investigating the rate at which algae produce various compounds by giving them 'heavy' water to grow on and seeing how quickly (on the scale of hours) this heavy hydrogen 'label' moves into the molecules they synthesize. This technique is powerful, but assumes that one knows the composition of the water the cells are using. Our results show that, over the course of a day, the water being used for synthesis is a 'moving target' independent of any added labels, something which must be accounted for when interpreting these experiments.

In addition to the direct scientific benefits of this project, the funding also enabled the investigator to participation in the Seattle MESA (Math, Engineering, and Science Achievement) marine biology/marine research Saturday Academy program. In addition to regular assistance with this program (which provides hands-on exposure to marine science/oceanography to, primarily, minority and female high school students) as a volunteer, the investigator served as a guest instructor, developing a curriculum and leading lab and field trip activities for an "Oceanography Day" each of the two years. The lesson materials and laboratory activities are now available for regular use by the program. Funds from the activities allowance also were used to enable a field trip for these students to the Seattle Aquarium to learn about scientific observation and hypothesis testing, and to make a day-long scientific sailing trip around the Puget Sound, learning about water quality, navigation, and the unique dynamics of freshwater-saltwater systems and their interaction with the land.

In addition to helping demonstrate the attraction of, and opportunities in, science to primarily women of color and new immigrants to the US with Seattle MESA, the funding enabled the investigator to help extensively with the professional development of a number of graduate students he worked with over the grant period. He provided technical expertise and mentorship which enabled their successful degree completion in the face of an unexpected and catastrophic loss of crucial personnel in the host laboratory.
